(AP Photo/Andrew Harnik) http://eapcontent.ap.org/jpg/2015/20150926/00/219a31a44a8a102b830f6a70670010db.jpg?contentid=219a31a44a8a102b830f6a70670010db/fmt=jpg/role=Preview/reldt=2015-09-26T00:22:38/media=Photo/recordid=f56a086751f04071b4fdcc65de79651f/itemid=f56a086751f04071b4fdcc65de79651f/objfilename=preview.jpg/authToken=eNotjU0KwyAUBk%2bkfO%2f5lyyEXkWNBReJQSPtwsM3hWxmmNXM%2fPVWGbcSLIMBMBPNVDzTGhQFLXRYgiBwFIvCW9jgYB1A2OIc3ad6XK3EcdXWX3H0cuR%2bo5ctN5nqPs%2bPf5IMZjm91fK%2bSfqbzA%2bsHye0&token=1443509402_59827FA87AF29DCE86407FDD2DDC6679 WASHINGTON (AP) — China's pledge to help crack down on hackers who steal commercial secrets from the United States, even coming as it did amid a bit of arm-twisting by President Barack Obama, is a big breakthrough that could reduce U.S.-China tensions and end huge losses for American companies.

The agreement may not be easy to enforce, particularly since it's often difficult to trace the source of cyberattacks and the Chinese government has never acknowledged a role in past attacks, said Betsy Page Sigman, a cybersecurity expert at Georgetown University's McDonough School of Business.

China’s pledge to help crack down on hackers who steal commercial secrets from the United States, even coming as it did amid a bit of arm-twisting by Obama, is a big breakthrough that could reduce U.S.-China tensions and end huge losses for American companies.

Trevor Nagel, a partner with the law firm White & Case who specializes in cybersecurity and other global technology issues, noted that China now has intellectual property of its own to protect, as it has become a world leader in manufacturing.

Malcolm Lee, nonresident senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and a former White House economic official, said that the Friday agreement will "begin to address one of the most destabilizing and corrosive issues in the relationship."

In this Sept. 25, 2015, photo, President Barack Obama, Chinese President Xi Jinping, first lady Michelle Obama and Jinping's wife Peng Liyuan descend the Grand Staircase as they arrive for a State Dinner at the White House in Washington.

When news of those plans appeared in the U.S. media, China dispatched a high-level delegation, led by Meng Jianzhu, the secretary of the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission of the Chinese Communist Party, to work out a deal.

Mark MacCarthy, vice president for public policy at the Software and Information Industry Association, said the tech industry trade group agrees with Obama that the cybertheft of intellectual property must stop.

Jeremie Waterman, executive director for China at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, called the agreement "a clear statement" on an issue of critical importance to the future of relations between the two countries.

said

The agreement sparks many questions, Robert Cattanach, a former Justice Department attorney who specializes in cybersecurity, says in an email: "How effective will the high-level consultations really be?
James Lewis, director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Strategic Technologies Program, said the thefts probably cost American companies tens of billions of dollars annually.
Last year the U.S. charged five officers in China's People Liberation Army for computer hacking and economic espionage against six U.S. companies, including Westinghouse, U.S. Steel and Alcoa.
Senior U.S. officials said the Obama administration had been preparing a package of sanctions in recent weeks aimed at China and other nations over cyberthefts of intellectual property.

Associated Press writers Martin Crutsinger and Marcy Gordon in Washington, Mae Anderson and Bree Fowler in New York, and Brandon Bailey in San Francisco contributed to this report.
Analysts say the agreement between the world's two biggest economies is just a start but could lead to real progress on the cybertheft issue — depending on how well it's implemented.
"I think it's a big deal," said Dmitri Alperovich, who published a seminal paper in 2011 identifying Chinese cyber economic espionage and now runs the cybersecurity firm Crowdstrike.
Analysts say the agreement between the world’s two biggest economies is just a start but could lead to real progress on the cybertheft issue, depending on how well it’s implemented.
North Korea, for instance, was quickly identified as the source of a hack last year that damaged computers at Sony and exposed internal emails at the filmmaker.
"Hopefully, it marks a new chapter," Waterman said, adding that, as with other areas of negotiation between the U.S. and China, the key will be implementation.
Will this affect China's well-known efforts to explore the vulnerability of the United States' power grid, financial sector and health industry?"
Also significant, Alperovich said, is the fact that the Chinese have agreed to provide responses to U.S. government requests for investigations.
"We are hopeful the understanding reached by the president and Chinese President Xi Jinping results in real progress on the ground," he said.
Despite questions yet to be answered, Tom Embrogno, founder of the cybersecurity firm Docupace, says of the agreement, "It's a first step."
"The Chinese government can use intermediaries" in such attacks, "and it can be very difficult for them to be found out," she said.
"For the first time ever, the Chinese have made a distinction between national security espionage and economic espionage."
"The Chinese thought about how unhappy that experience was, and they didn't want to go through it again," he said.
The U.S. has accused Beijing of backing Chinese hackers who steal trade secrets from American companies.
Obama announced the agreement at a joint news conference Friday with Chinese President Xi Jinping.
Will spying by private Chinese companies "simply replace state-sponsored economic espionage?"
"The thing that got the Chinese to the table is the threat of sanctions," Alperovich said.
"That made them think, 'We're not going to be able to get away with this,'" Lewis said.
"They can't just shrug and say, 'We don't do hacking; hacking is illegal,'" he said.
Before the Xi summit, Obama called cybertheft by China "an act of aggression."
The U.S. also has been getting better at tracking the source of cyberattacks.
Last year's indictments helped, too, Lewis said.
"They knew the Americans were really worked up."
The result was Friday's announcement.
